clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Short Term Versus Long Term Treatment With Seton Prior to LIFT Surgery for Complex Anal Fistula
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Short Term Versus Long Term Treatment With Seton Prior to LIFT Surgery for Complex Anal Fistula, a Randomized Controlled Trial.

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to compare short term (3 week) with long term (6 months) treatment with seton prior to LIFT surgery. The main end-points are recurrence rates and complication rates after surgery.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Unable to get MRI of patients within reasonable time on a local hospital.

primary_outcome.description: Recurrence or non-healing of anal fistula one year after LIFT surgery
Main complication being anal incontinence measured by St.Marks score, but all major and minor complications are registered.

arm_group.description: Seton through fistula 6 months prior to LIFT
Seton through fistula 3 weeks prior to LIFT surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age between 20 and 65 years
- Complex anal fistula defined as
- anterior fistulas in women
- branched fistulas
- fistulas in patients with anal incontinence
- fistulas traversing more than 30% of the anal sphincter and therefore unsuitable for simple division.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Crohn's disease in the rectum
- Previous LIFT surgery on same side
- Patient already treated with seton > 3 weeks
- Not able or willing to sign informed consent
